com.SIMRacingApps.Connectors

Class Connector

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.SIMRacingApps.Connectors.Connector
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    iRacingConnector

    public class Connector
extends java.lang.Object
    The Connector Class defines a generic interface for retrieving SIM data. SIMulators should inherit this class and override the methods for which it can provide data for. Each SIM should try to return the same set of enumerated values defined by the overridden method to allow clients to make hard coded decisions based on those. It doesn't have to do this if the data is to simply be displayed. I will have to admit, I based these on iRacing (my primary SIM), so other SIMs will have to conform.

    There are many methods for this class, but also there is a method called getData(), that takes a string that is formatted using a RESTfull syntax and calls the corresponding method. This is a little slower than calling the methods directly. It was designed to be used by the web interface. There is also an overloaded version of getData() that takes each string as a separate argument. If the first argument doesn't map to one of the public methods of this class, then if it matches the SIM name, it will pass it down to the SIM layer to process it. See getData(String) for details.

    • Data d = connector.getData("/Car/LEADER/Lap/Current"); //Note: the leading slash is optional
    • Data d = connector.getData("/iRacing/SessionInfo/Sessions/1/ResultsPositions/0/LapsCompleted"); //SIM specific, not recommended
    • Data d = connector.getSIMData("SessionInfo","Sessions","1","ResultsPositions","0","LapsCompleted"); //SIM specific, not recommended

    For most methods that need a car identifier, the default will be "REFERENCE" if a car is not specified. "REFERENCE" refers to "ME" unless changed by a client. Clients can change it to get a different prospective, such as when spectating.

    A lot of the methods are overloaded to provide defaults for missing arguments.

        public Data setRecord(java.lang.String Filename)

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • setStartingVersion

        public Data setStartingVersion(java.lang.String startingversion)

        Parameters:
        startingversion - The starting version in the format specified by the SIM.
        Returns:
        The starting version in a Data container.

        public Data getEndingVersion()

      • getData

        public Data getData(java.lang.String path)
             throws Connector.ConnectorException
        This version of getData(String path) takes a path to a value and returns the result. The path is formatted like a URL with slashes as separators. A leading slash is optional.

        This method was designed to be called by the web interface, where only a string path needed to make a call to get data. For Java Client developers, you can still use this function, but you loose the compile time error checking that you would get by calling the methods directly.

        First, the first argument is tested to see if it matches a public method on this class that takes the same number of String arguments, then calls it. If it's a "get", the "get" is optional, but "set", "decrement", and "increment" are required.

        Second, the first argument is tested to see if it matches the name of the SIM. If so, passes all the arguments to the SIM version of getSIMData(String...args). It is not recommended to call the SIM version directly as this will tie your client to that SIM. Although you will have to use it if the API is missing something you need, consider enhancing the standard API instead.

        For Example:

        • Data d = connector.getData("/Car/LEADER/Lap/Current"); //Note: the leading slash is optional
        • Data d = connector.getData("/iRacing/SessionInfo/Sessions/1/ResultsPositions/0/LapsCompleted");
        Parameters:
        path - The path to the requested value with arguments separated by slashes in a RESTfull syntax.
        Returns:
        null if return value is void, else the value in a Data container. If the path was invalid, then it returns an error message in a Data container with the State set to ERROR.
        Throws:
        Connector.ConnectorException - for other syntax or runtime errors

      • isActive

        public boolean isActive()
        3 methods work together to poll the SIM for data (isActive, waitForDataReady, isConnected). I have built a dispatcher, see ConnectorDispatcherImpl, that polls the SIM for data using these methods, then calls callback functions.

        isActive() is called first and every time through the loop. It returns true if the SIM is ready to accept calls. The SIM can return false for various reasons, with the default action would be to exit your program because of a fatal error. It could also mean you have reached the end of a recorded file that you told it to play. In that case, you might want to simply start it over.

        waitForDataReady() is called to see if the SIM has any data. It should return true when data is available from the SIM. A return of false means no data was available and you should try again. Each SIM should put any throttling in this implementation to be nice to other processes and prevent a tight loop.

        isConnected() will return true if the SIM is running, false if not.

        The following code illustrates how to use these methods. 

         while (connector.isActive()) {
     if (connector.waitForDataReady()) {
         //call connector.getData(datapath);
     }
     else {
         if (!connector.isConnected()) {
             //handle SIM not running
             //call connector.getData(datapath); //is allowed here
         }
     }
 }
        Simulators should override these abstract methods and implement them.
        Returns:
        true or false

      • waitForDataReady

      • getSession

        public Session getSession()
        Returns an instance to the SIM session. Each SIM should override this method and return a SIM specific session instance.
        Returns:
